description: From Middle English pinappel (“pinecone”, literally “pine-apple/pine-fruit”), equivalent to pine +‎ apple. Later applied to the fruit of the pineapple plant due to its resemblance to a pinecone. Compare the Middle Dutch and Dutch pĳnappel, the Middle Low German pinappel, the Old High German pīnapful, the Middle High German pīnaphel, and the early Modern German pinapfel — all in the sense of “pine cone”. Compare also the post-Classical Latin pomum pini, the Old French pume de pin, the Middle French and French pomme de pin and Spanish piña.

entries.meaning: A tropical plant, Ananas comosus, native to South America, having thirty or more long, spined and pointed leaves surrounding a thick stem.
The ovoid fruit of the pineapple plant, which has very sweet white or yellow flesh, a tough, spiky shell and a tough, fibrous core.
(uncountable) The flesh of a pineapple fruit used as a food item.
A web burrfish (Chilomycterus antillarum, syn. Chilomycterus geometricus)
A light yellow colour, like that of pineapple flesh (also called pineapple yellow).
(obsolete or dialectal) A pinecone; the cone of the fir.
A decorative carving of a pineapple fruit used as a symbol of hospitality.
(slang) A hand grenade. (From the similarity to the shape of a pineapple fruit.)
A hairstyle consisting of a ponytail worn on top of the head, imitating the leaves of a pineapple.
